title: 109_hr3586
content: The "Small Business Protection Act of 2005" may be cited as such. The "Small Business Protection Act of 2005" acknowledges the importance of small businesses in the economy, highlighting their role in job creation, unique challenges in accessing capital, market volatility, regulatory costs, and the need for tax code reforms to address these issues. The "Small Business Protection Act of 2005" aims to provide employees salaries and benefits, ensure small business solvency during recessions, encourage business formation and growth, promote charitable giving, and stimulate the national economy through increased employment and capital generation. It introduces Small Business Protection Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code to support these goals. The Small Business Protection Act of 2005 introduces Small Business Protection Accounts allowing deductions for cash payments made by eligible small business individuals. The deduction amount is limited to 50% of the taxpayer's net profit attributable to any trade or business. Excess limitations can be carried over to the following year. The Small Business Protection Act of 2005 introduces Small Business Protection Accounts for eligible small businesses, with deductions limited to 50% of net profit from the trade or business. The term 'Small Business Protection Account' refers to a trust created for the exclusive benefit of the taxpayer, with specific requirements for contributions and trustee qualifications. The Small Business Protection Account rules include provisions on loss of exemption, prohibited transactions, pledging account as security, community property laws, and custodial accounts. Payments are deemed made on the last day of the taxable year if made on or before the due date for filing the tax return. The term "Individual" is defined for this section. A report on the implementation and effectiveness of section 468C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 must be submitted by the Administrator of the Small Business Administration within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The Small Business Development Center Program is designated as the lead agency for assisting small businesses with Small Business Protection Accounts. The Internal Revenue Service will provide necessary assistance to the Small Business Administration for this purpose.
